message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest that he is suffering from excoriation disorder, also known as skin-picking disorder. This disorder is treated with selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) such as fluoxetine. Clomipramine is also an option but is less commonly used. Dialectical behavioral therapy can also be helpful, but SSRIs are typically used as a first-line treatment. Interpersonal psychotherapy is not typically used for this disorder.

Clomipramine is also an option, but SSRIs are generally preferred due to a better side effect profile. Dialectical behavioral therapy can be helpful in addition to medication, but medication is typically the first line approach. Interpersonal psychotherapy is not indicated for this condition.

Interpersonal psychotherapy is not a first-line treatment for skin picking disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is displaying symptoms of a condition called skin picking disorder or excoriation disorder. Fluoxetine, a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), has been shown to be effective for this disorder. Clomipramine, another medication option, is also effective but has more side effects. Dialectical behavior therapy (DBT) is a type of therapy that has been shown to be effective for this disorder, but medication may be necessary in addition to therapy. Interpersonal psychotherapy is not a recommended treatment for skin picking disorder.

Fluoxetine is an SSRI medication that is commonly used to manage OCD symptoms. Dialectical behavioral therapy may also be used as a supportive measure, but medication management should be initiated first.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is displaying symptoms of excoriation disorder, also known as skin picking disorder. Among the options, fluoxetine, a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), is the most appropriate initial medication because it can reduce obsessive-compulsive tendencies. Clomipramine is another medication that can reduce such tendencies, but it has more side effects than fluoxetine. Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) is also a recommended treatment for excoriation disorder. Dialectical behavioral therapy (DBT) is a type of CBT that may be effective for patients with borderline personality disorder or those with self-harming tendencies. Interpersonal psychotherapy focuses on interpersonal relationships and may not be as effective for treating excoriation disorder.
